results.title: Macintosh Classic
results.brief_description: If you took a computer class in Australia during the early 1990s, chances are you used one of these boxy personal computers. The Macintosh Classic was released in October 1990 and was the first Macintosh computer to sell for less than $1,000 US dollars, making it one of the most affordable computers on the market at the time. It was really just a cheaper version of the Macintosh SE without as many features, which had been released in 1987, and the Macintosh Classic was seen by some as an attempt to squeeze a few more years out of the earlier model. Part of its reduced cost was due to being made in Singapore, instead of America like previous Macintosh computers. Still, the price and stable operating system made it popular in schools, at home and for small business.

results.title: TVG-8610C Console
results.brief_description: Console with power cable purchased on ebay February 2020
results.description: The Hanimex TVG-8610C is an early television games console circa 1978. This two-player console has detachable joysticks with 10 internally programmed games (similar to Pong) and allows the player to customise difficulty levels, automation, and keep score.
description_for_label: Console with power cable purchased on ebay February 2020

results.title: Ohnar 16MM Editor Viewer
results.brief_description: Film viewing and editing devices like the Ohnar provided amatuer filmmakers the ability to precisely edit their own home movies with relative ease. Popular among avid consumer-level filmmakers for their size, this 16mm film equipment allows hand cranking and has a convenient frame counting dial. The reel arms can be swivelled out and locked in place for use, and folded away for compact storage.

group_siblings.title: 16mm projector
group_siblings.material_description:
-Ditmar 16mm projector no 2072
 - Internal cloth bound board used as a platform to store inside box.
 - Grey cord w Aus plug and a black cord w Euro plug.
 - Detachable feed arm
 - Huile Oil Ol original cardboard box and glass oil bottle inside.  The oil bottle still has 3 mm of oil at bottom which is fluid.  The cork lid of the bottle also has a tiny metal straw protruding from it to gather the oil.
 - Singer (brand) oil pourer with a removable nozzle.  Not from this set, but owner must have used it as one of many methods to oil the projector.
 - Tiny metal funnel for pouring oil into oil dropper.
 - One glass dropper with rubber end which is stored inside a cylindrical tube with lid.
 - One clear plastic dropper with remnants of oil inside top round squeezer.
 - Australian plug with nothing connected.
 - A small Euro plug which is backed on to wood and slots in the back of the machine.
 - An old paper rag
 - 2 spare belts in very delicate wax paper bags.  One of rubber (hardened) and one finely coiled metal (which has a kink in it).

results.title: 16MM Sound Projector, RST Series
results.brief_description:
Introduced in the 1920’s as a more affordable film format to the industry standard 35mm, 16mm film was popularised by home movie enthusiasts and widely used for educational purposes. Projectors like this Hanimex Eiki 16MM increasingly became a common piece of audio visual equipment within schools and libraries across the world. This particular projector features textured metal casing and a handle for portability convenience.

The popularity of 16mm projectors began to decrease in the 1980’s as home video technologies were seen as a more cost effective and compact solution to film.

results.title: 16mm projector
results.material_description:
-Ditmar 16mm projector no 2072
 - Internal cloth bound board used as a platform to store inside box.
 - Grey cord w Aus plug and a black cord w Euro plug.
 - Detachable feed arm
 - Huile Oil Ol original cardboard box and glass oil bottle inside.  The oil bottle still has 3 mm of oil at bottom which is fluid.  The cork lid of the bottle also has a tiny metal straw protruding from it to gather the oil.
 - Singer (brand) oil pourer with a removable nozzle.  Not from this set, but owner must have used it as one of many methods to oil the projector.
 - Tiny metal funnel for pouring oil into oil dropper.
 - One glass dropper with rubber end which is stored inside a cylindrical tube with lid.
 - One clear plastic dropper with remnants of oil inside top round squeezer.
 - Australian plug with nothing connected.
 - A small Euro plug which is backed on to wood and slots in the back of the machine.
 - An old paper rag
 - 2 spare belts in very delicate wax paper bags.  One of rubber (hardened) and one finely coiled metal (which has a kink in it).
results.brief_description:
Introduced in the 1920’s as a more affordable film format to the industry standard 35mm, 16mm film was popularised by home movie enthusiasts and widely used for educational purposes. Projectors like this Ditmar 16mm became a common piece of audio visual equipment in classrooms and libraries across the world. The popularity of 16mm projectors decreased in the 1980’s as home video technologies were seen as a more cost effective and compact solution to film.

This particular projector belonged to amateur filmmaker Kenneth Rankine, whose collection of home movies and film equipment were generously donated to ACMI by his granddaughter.

This particular projector belonged to amateur filmmaker Kenneth Rankine, whose collection of home movies and film equipment were generously donated to ACMI by his granddaughter.

results.title: In Conversation with Tully Arnot
results.headline_credit: Melbourne, Victoria, Australia and Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 24 APR 2019
results.brief_description: In conversation with artist Tully Arnot and ACMI curator Shelley McSpedden to discuss the development of his new work Epiphytes as the Mordant Family VR Commission’s recipient.

results.title: Pair of Commodore C-1342 Joysticks
results.brief_description: Pair of brown Commodore joysticks with red ‘fire’ button compatible with Commodore 64 systems. The user may push in one of eight directions, and a fire button. The control stick is mechanically connected to four switches; up, down, left and right. Pushing the stick in a direction in between two of these ‘cardinal directions’ activates two of the four switches.
